Suppose that battery life is a normal random variable with μ = 8 and σ = 1.2. Using the standard deviation rule, what is the probability that a randomly chosen battery will last between 6.8 and 9.2 hours?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the probability that a chosen battery will last less than 8 hours. Determine how many standard deviations away from the mean the value 6.8 and 9.2 are and then use the standard deviation rule to determine the probability.
Correct. The given range 6.8 to 9.2 is within 1 standard deviation of the mean, so the probability battery life will lie in this range is 0.68.

Suppose that battery life is a normal random variable with μ = 8 and σ = 1.2. How likely is it that a randomly chosen battery lasts longer than 10.4 hours?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the probability that a chosen battery will last less than 8 hours. Determine how many standard deviations away from the mean the value 10.4 is and then determine what probability lies above this value.

Incorrect. This is the probability that a chosen battery will last less than 5.6 hours. Determine how many standard deviations away from the mean the value 10.4 is and then determine what probability lies above this value.

Incorrect. This is the probability that a chosen battery will last longer than 10.4 hours or less than 5.6 hours. It appears you forgot to divide the probability by 2. Determine how many standard deviations away from the mean the value 10.4 is and then determine what probability lies above this value.
Correct. 10.4 is 2 standard deviations above the mean of 8. To calculate probability above this point: 1 − 0.95 = 0.05/2 = 0.025.
